content.value: The government has committed to reviewing Australia’s “sham” carbon credit system after a whistleblower revealed that up to 80% of Australian carbon credits are fraudulent.

The Albanese government kicked off an independent review of Australia’s carbon credits system shortly after winning the election, in response to a whistleblower alleging up to 80% of carbon credits in Australia are a “sham”.

Andrew Macintosh is a professor at Australian National University and has worked in climate policy for more than 20 years. Among many other roles he chaired the Domestic Offsets and Integrity Committee, which oversees the method for the carbon trading scheme, for six and a half years. Macintosh has been a part of establishing the carbon trading system in Australia, is embedded in Australia’s climate policy world and is a believer in environmental markets.

He’s now turned whistleblower though. He is calling for the Clean Energy Regulator, which regulates Australian Carbon Credit Units to be broken up, citing serious conflicts of interest and a history of low-integrity management.
Last year, the Wilmot Cattle Company - based in Ebor, on the Northern Tablelands of NSW - made a groundbreaking deal with Microsoft.
